Award.AwardTitle: NCS-FO: The role of noise in mental exploration for learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
What makes people behave so differently from one another? Consider how we make decisions. Some people are quick and decisive but overly rigid, unable to adapt effectively to new opportunities or threats. In contrast, others may be more deliberative and less confident, making their decisions less predictable but more adaptable to changing circumstances. With funding from the National Science Foundation, Drs. Joshua Gold and Joseph Kable of the University of Pennsylvania are investigating a new theory that in the real world, there is a fundamental tradeoff between these two extremes. The theory includes a novel proposal that what has previously been dismissed by researchers as random variability in human behavior might instead reflect uncertain, adaptable decision-making linked with norepinephrine, a neurochemical implicated in learning and arousal. Does this characteristic explain other aspects of human personality and behavior? Can norepinephrine levels in the brain be manipulated to affect complex learning and decision-making behaviors? In answering these questions, this work will establish foundational, basic knowledge that, in the long term, will help to guide the development of new tools to diagnose and counteract conditions associated with abnormal learning and decision-making, including attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), anxiety, depression, and schizophrenia. This knowledge about individual differences in learning will also inform how to best tailor educational and learning practices, as well as how to design computer programs that learn adaptively from experience. Other benefits of this work are resources that will assist research and education in cognitive and neural systems, including publically available datasets, computer code and machine learning algorithms; increased participation of underrepresented groups in this kind of integrative research, via summer research experiences for high school and undergraduate students; and an increased public awareness of neuroscience via public lectures, Brain Awareness Week activities, and contributions to a website that explains brain research in laymen's terms.

The work is based on a novel hypothesis about brain mechanisms that are responsible for certain idiosyncratic learning and decision processes. Specifically, in our unpredictable world, decision-makers face an inherent trade-off: higher certainty leads to more precise and accurate choices when the world is stable but an inability to adjust to change, whereas less certainty can lead to greater adaptability but also more variable and imprecise decisions. The investigators propose that this trade-off is regulated by interactions between arousal and cortical systems. To test this hypothesis, they use an interdisciplinary and integrative set of approaches with three primary objectives: 1) develop a theoretical framework describing inherent trade-offs between output stability and learning in hierarchical, probabilistic inference processes in unpredictable environments; 2) identify behavioral, physiological, and neural correlates of variability in how individuals navigate these trade-offs while making choices in unpredictable environments; and 3) identify causal influences of the brainstem nucleus locus coeruleus, a key component of the arousal system, on the variability in adaptive inference. The work forges meaningful connections across theory and experiment, spanning multiple spatial and temporal scales and levels of abstraction, to identify computational and physiological underpinnings of individual differences in learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In dynamic, real-world environments, our ability to draw effective conclusions from incomplete or ambiguous evidence is often challenged by two important sources of uncertainty that can be difficult to distinguish from each other but prescribe very different courses of action: noise, which often represents irrelevant fluctuations that should be ignored, and volatility, which often represents relevant changes that should be used to update beliefs. For example, a stock price may show noisy, day-to-day fluctuations that have little or no bearing on the long-term value of the company, but the same stock price will occasionally experience a volatile change-point (e.g., in response to a change in leadership of the company) that corresponds to a real change in value. The goal of this project was to understand how the brain accounts for these different forms of uncertainty when making decisions. We focused on two key aspects of this problem. The first is that both forms of uncertainty are reflected in measures of physiological arousal including pupil diameter. The second is that there tends to be a great deal of variability in terms of how individuals make decisions under these conditions. To better understand and unify these findings, we developed a novel theoretical framework based on a concept from machine learning known as the “bias-variance trade-off,” according to which more complex models can account for more features of the world (i.e., they tend to exhibit less bias) but are also more susceptible to noisy information that can degrade their predictive abilities (i.e., they also tend to exhibit more variance). We showed that this trade-off is also relevant to human decision-making abilities in dynamic environments. Specifically, some people use more complex models, or strategies, to form decisions that result in lower biases (i.e., an enhanced ability to respond effectively to real, volatile changes) but also higher variance (i.e., a tendency to see noise as volatility). In contrast, others use less complex models, resulting in higher bias but lower variance. We believe that this principle has broad applicability to individual differences in a wide range of decision-making tasks and behaviors. We also gained insights into brain mechanisms responsible for managing this trade-off. For example, we showed that the across-subject differences in strategy complexity were reflected in certain aspects of non-luminance-mediated changes in pupil diameter, a component of physiological arousal. We further related these arousal-related signals to activation patterns of neurons in the brainstem nucleus locus coeruleus, the brain’s primary source of the neuromodulator norepinephrine (NE). Finally, we showed that these decisions involve changes in multivariate brain activity patterns and in functional connectivity between certain brain regions. Together these results support a newly emerging picture of how the brain uses interactions between arousal and cognition, implemented via NE-based modulation of brain connectivity patterns, to support flexible and idiosyncratic decision processes in dynamic environments.

Our work also has provided a number of important broader impacts. Through the research itself, we developed and disseminated resources, including behavioral and physiological datasets and analytic tools, that will benefit research and education in cognitive and neural systems. Through research-related activities, we encouraged the participation of underrepresented groups in this kind of integrative research, via summer research experiences for high school and undergraduate students. Through activities complementary to the research, including public lectures, Brain Awareness Week activities, and contributions to a website that explains brain research in laymen’s terms, we increased public awareness of neuroscience.
